div.p: This paper solves consensus problems for networked agents whose interactions with each other are described by signed digraphs. The Laplacian matrix of a signed digraph is studied by introducing rooted cycles, and the relationship between it and the spanning tree condition is addressed. In particular, the Laplacian matrix of a signed digraph with spanning trees is positive stable if and only if there is at least one negative rooted cycle; otherwise, it has exactly one zero eigenvalue if and only if either there exist no rooted cycles or all existing rooted cycles are positive. It is shown that all agents reach interval bipartite consensus if their associated signed digraph has a spanning tree. Further, the consensus values of all agents depend only on the initial states of those agents which are associated with root vertices. The developed consensus results are applicable for multi-agent systems with both continuous-time and discrete-time dynamics. Illustrative examples are provided to demonstrate interval bipartite consensus performances for multiagent systems associated with different signed digraphs which all contain spanning trees but are not strongly connected.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A. Motivations M ULTI-AGENT systems have been considered one of the hottest topics in the area of network control for the past decade. Their coordination control has many applications, such as explaining natural phenomena and providing guidelines for practical tasks of those complex systems that consist of a group of mobile agents [1]- [8]. In general, the agents form a network to perform cooperative tasks for the group through interactions which are represented by graphs with all positive edge weights. This feature results in the distributed structure for coordination controllers conducted by the nearest neighbor interaction rules, under which consensus is considered one of the basic problems for multi-agent systems (see also surveys and books [9]- [13]).

Consensus of networked agents means to develop a protocol such that they can agree on a common quantity, which depends on the initial states of all agents [9]. It has been shown that the connectivity of the associated undirected graph with networked multi-agent systems provides their consensus with a necessary and sufficient guarantee. When it comes to consensus of multiagent networks under the general directed graphs (digraphs for short), the necessary and sufficient condition is that the related digraphs have a spanning tree [5] or a globally reachable vertex [3], whereas the strong connectivity of the related digraphs just is sufficient but not necessary [2], [9]. Moreover, the developed consensus results are applicable for both continuous-time and discrete-time multi-agent systems. It is worth noting, however, that the aforementioned (in fact most of the existing) consensus results focus on the networked multi-agent systems which only admit cooperative interactions between agents.

Recently, the idea of consensus has been extended to general multi-agent systems operating on such networks that can allow the agents to possess not only cooperative but also antagonistic interactions [14]- [24]. In other words, the graph that represents communications between agents is signed, in which there exist edges associated with positive and negative adjacency weights. Networks of agents associated with signed graphs are common especially in the area of social networks ( [14], [15], [25], [26]), where a positive/negative weight can describe, e.g., like/dislike and trust/distrust interactions between agents. By investigating a class of so-called bipartite consensus problems, not only have promising consensus results been established, but also possible extensions have been investigated for, e.g., modulus consensus [27], [28], bipartite formation [29]- [31], and bipartite flocking [32] issues on networked agents associated with signed graphs.

The aim of bipartite consensus is to develop a protocol such that the agents can reach agreement regarding a quantity which is the same for all agents in modulus but not in sign [15]. Most existing bipartite consensus results, however, require structural balance of the associated signed graphs (e.g., see [16]- [24]). In addition, the basic connectivity assumption on communication between vertices, i.e., the connectivity of undirected graphs or strong connectivity of digraphs is needed to develop consensus results on networked multi-agent systems which are associated with signed graphs [15], [17], [24], especially associated with structurally unbalanced signed graphs [18]- [21]. In contrast to this, a weaker connectivity condition that the associated graph with networked multi-agent systems contains a spanning tree is necessary and sufficient to guarantee consensus for the special case where all the edge adjacency weights are positive [10]. In particular, it has been simulated in [16], [22] that there may be various consensus performances for networked agents if their associated signed digraphs are structurally unbalanced but can only meet the spanning tree condition. However, regarding this observed consensus problem of networked agents under signed digraphs, there have been reported no theoretical investigations until now to the best of our knowledge.

div.head: B. Contributions
div.p: Motivated by the previous discussions, we aim to answer the following questions for consensus of networked agents that are associated with general signed digraphs, regardless of whether they are structurally balanced or structurally unbalanced.

1) What is the fundamental consensus result for multi-agent systems associated with general signed digraphs that are not strongly connected but only contain spanning trees? 2) How can the consensus performance be characterized for multi-agent systems when the associated signed digraphs only contain spanning trees? 3) Can the consensus results, which are obtained for agents with interactions described by signed digraphs with only spanning trees, be applicable to multi-agent systems with both continuous-time and discrete-time dynamics?

We introduce a notion of interval bipartite consensus, where those agents associated with roots of signed digraphs (hereafter called root agents) reach bipartite consensus and the remaining agents converge and the converged values of them are not more than those of root agents in modulus. If the associated signed digraph contains a spanning tree, then all agents reach interval bipartite consensus, which is also illustrated through examples. In particular, when the signed digraph is structurally balanced, interval bipartite consensus collapses into bipartite consensus. When the root agents achieve the state stability, the states of all agents are stable. It suggests that the proposed interval bipartite consensus, including as a special case the bipartite consensus, plays a fundamental role when signed digraphs with spanning trees represent interactions between agents.

To clearly characterize the consensus performance of agents, we exploit the Laplacian matrix of a signed digraph containing spanning trees by introducing a notion of rooted cycles which denote the cycles consisting of roots of the signed digraph. The Laplacian matrix of a signed digraph containing spanning trees is positive stable, i.e., all its eigenvalues have positive real parts if and only if there exists at least one negative rooted cycle, and it has exactly one zero eigenvalue and all the other eigenvalues have positive real parts if and only if there do not exist rooted cycles or the existing rooted cycles are all positive. With these results on Laplacian matrices, the multi-agent system under a signed digraph with spanning trees achieves the state stability if and only if there exists at least one negative rooted cycle, and it achieves the interval bipartite consensus with the converged values of all agents depending only on the initial states of those root agents if and only if there do not exist rooted cycles or the existing rooted cycles are all positive. This extends the typical consensus and bipartite consensus results (see, e.g., [10], [15]).

We consider the consensus analysis for not only continuoustime but also discrete-time multi-agent systems. With the stepsize chosen appropriately, it is shown that the consensus results developed for continuous-time multi-agent systems can be also generalized to discrete-time multi-agent systems when they are associated with signed digraphs that have spanning trees. This benefits from the matrix analysis theory [33], which also is the same as the classical consensus results for multi-agent systems under digraphs with all positive edge weights (see, e.g., [10]).

div.head: C. Paper Organizations
div.p: We organize the remaining parts of this paper as follows. We give basic notations and some preliminaries on signed digraphs and bipartite consensus of multi-agent systems in Section II. The observed consensus problems are presented in Section III, together with the corresponding illustrations. In Section IV, we propose properties for the Laplacian matrix of a signed digraph that has a spanning tree. The consensus results for continuoustime multi-agent systems are developed in Section V, and then their extensions to discrete-time multi-agent systems are made in Section VI. We finally conclude this paper in Section VII.

div.head: III. INTERVAL BIPARTITE CONSENSUS PROBLEMS
div.p: As pointed out in [15], gauge transformations can be carried out to transform consensus problems under signed graphs into the corresponding traditional consensus problems under graphs with the pure positive edge adjacency weights when the signed graphs are structurally balanced. It yields a good property such that the bipartite consensus problem of agents described by (3) has alternative solutions due to the well established traditional consensus results after the implementation of a suitable gauge transformation. However, we do not have such good alternative ways to the consensus problems under structurally unbalanced signed graphs, and most of the existing results can only instead achieve the state stability of agents. But, in fact, there are more other attractive consensus performances than state stability for the agents given by (3) when subject to structurally unbalanced signed digraphs (see also [16], [22] for similar discussions).

In addition, the consensus results of [15] for the system (3) under signed graphs need the connectivity of undirected graphs and strong connectivity of digraphs. However, this may impose restrictions on the application of consensus results of the multiagent systems under signed graphs (see also [16], [20]- [23]). In contrast, for the multi-agent systems under traditional digraphs whose edge weights are all positive, a necessary and sufficient guarantee to consensus of them is the spanning tree condition, which is weaker than the strong connectivity (see, e.g., [10]).

Summarizing, we can see a more general consensus problem than bipartite consensus for the system (3) as follows: (Q) What will the convergence performance of the system (3) be when it is associated with signed digraphs which only contain spanning trees? If it can still achieve "consensus", how many different values are there in the final stationary states of agents?

div.head: B. Interval Bipartite Consensus
div.p: To answer the aforementioned question (Q), we will address the problem formally presented in the following definition. Definition 1: We say that the system (3) reaches interval bipartite consensus if lim t→∞ |x i (t)| ≤ θ , ∀i ∈ I n , where θ > 0 is the modulus of the converged values of root agents. Moreover, the number of elements in x(∞) whose moduli are equal to θ is called the impact index of root agents.

In particular, if only equalities occur, i.e., lim t→∞ |x i (t)| = θ , ∀i ∈ I n , interval bipartite consensus of Definition 1 collapses into bipartite consensus of [15,Definition 1]. Obviously, Definition 1 presents a more general consensus problem, including (bipartite) consensus as a special case, which to our knowledge has not been studied yet. If θ = 0 is also admitted in Definition 1, then state stability can be viewed as a special case of interval bipartite consensus. Based on these observations, we will show that interval bipartite consensus can provide exactly the answer to the question (Q).

By Definition 1, µ is adopted to represent the impact index of root agents. It actually discloses the number of agents which reach agreement (with root agents) in modulus but not in sign. The larger µ is, the more agents are influenced by root agents to directly achieve bipartite consensus. In addition to this direct influence, indirect influence of root agents is also incorporated in Definition 1. Though each agent may not exactly follow the root agents, it must be influenced to limit its behavior into the symmetric bounds decided by them. In Example 1, µ = 4 and θ = 5/4 in Fig. 2(c), where the agents v j , j = 3, 4 follow root agents v i , i = 1, 2 and the remaining agents v k are influenced such that |x k (∞)| < θ , k = 5, 6. Similar analysis can be derived for Fig. 2(d).

div.head: IV. LAPLACIAN MATRICES OF SIGNED DIGRAPHS
div.p: With (3), it is easy to see that the Laplacian matrix L decides the consensus performances for multi-agent systems associated with signed digraphs. It follows also from the aforementioned illustrations that more consensus performances arise when the signed digraph G is not strongly connected but has a spanning tree. Motivated by such observations, we study the relationship between the spanning tree condition of signed digraphs and the properties of their corresponding Laplacian matrices.

div.head: A. Rooted Cycles
div.p: We introduce a notion of "rooted cycle" for digraphs as well as some related properties.
Definition 2: A cycle in a digraph G is called a rooted cycle if it contains some (not necessarily all) roots of G .

The property P7) follows directly from definitions and properties of rooted cycles and strong connectivity of digraphs. Note also that the properties P1)-P7) hold for digraphs regardless of whether or not they are signed graphs. By utilizing the property P7), we introduce the following proposition which establishes the relationship between the structural balance (or unbalance) and rooted cycles of strongly connected signed digraphs. Proposition 2: A strongly connected signed digraph G has the following two equivalent properties: P8) G is structurally balanced if and only if the rooted cycles of G are all positive; P9) G is structurally unbalanced if and only if G has at least one negative rooted cycle. Proof: This proposition can be proved using the property P7) as well as properties of strongly connected signed digraphs (see, e.g., [15], [25] for more details).

Remark 1: Actually, it is said that G is structurally balanced when all of its cycles are positive [15], [25]. From the property P7), it follows that all the cycles of a strongly connected signed digraph are rooted cycles, as adopted in Proposition 2. Besides, the property P7) implies that when the signed digraph G is not strongly connected, its cycles can be not rooted cycles. We can see, however, that Proposition 2 holds if and only if the cycles of a signed digraph are rooted cycles. Clearly, this implies that rooted cycles play a fundamental role in applying Proposition 2 for signed digraphs. With this observation, we are interested in rooted cycles for general consensus analysis to be developed under non-strongly connected signed digraphs in the sequel.

div.head: B. Properties of Laplacian Matrices
div.p: We first propose a basic theorem to disclose the relationship between the spanning tree condition of signed digraphs and the eigenvalue distribution of their Laplacian matrices.

Theorem 1: If a signed digraph G has a spanning tree, then the Laplacian matrix L satisfies either the following result R1) or R2): R1) there exists exactly one zero eigenvalue and all the other eigenvalues of L have positive real parts; R2) all the eigenvalues of L have positive real parts.

For a particular case of the signed digraph G where its edge weights are all positive, it follows that its Laplacian matrix L satisfies the result R1) if and only if G has a spanning tree (see, e.g., [5]). This is clearly different from the result proposed in Theorem 1, which is a general property for Laplacian matrices of signed digraphs. It will be shown that if the signed digraph G has additional structural properties which are more relaxed than the requirements of [5], the result of Theorem 1 becomes necessary and sufficient (see the following Corollary 1). When however, it comes to the general case addressed in Theorem 1, we no longer have the benefits of these additional properties. It is not difficult to see that the necessity of Theorem 1 does not hold. The next example provides this with a counterexample.
Example 2: Consider a trivial case for the signed digraph G , consisting of
div.formula: N separate components G 1 , G 2 , • • • , G N which are all strongly connected. It is clear that G does not have spanning trees, where L takes a block-diagonal form of L = diag{L 1 , L 2 , • • • , L N } and L i , i = 1, 2, • • • , N denotes the Laplacian matrix of G i .
div.p: However, it is easy to get with [15, Lemma 2 and Corollary 3] that the result R1) holds when one of the strongly connected signed digraphs G i , i = 1, 2, • • • , N is structurally balanced and all others are structurally unbalanced, and the result R2) holds when all
div.formula: G i , i = 1, 2, • • • , N are structurally unbalanced.
div.p: By contrast, the proof of Theorem 1 is not easy to establish. Since we no longer have the strong connectivity condition, the analysis method in [15] does not work, and also those analysis approaches based on the Gershgorin circle theorem (see [33]) are not applicable. In fact, if we consider the Gershgorin circle theorem for L, then by (4), we can only get that the eigenvalues of L are all in the closed right half plane of the complex plane, and its eigenvalues with zero real parts must be zero. However, we can not determine whether L has zero eigenvalues and how many zero eigenvalues it has. Moreover, the existence and the number of zero eigenvalues play a crucial role in convergence performance of the system (3). It is also important to determine under what conditions L has or does not have zero eigenvalues. To address these issues as well as obtain the proof of Theorem 1, we present some properties for the Laplacian matrix L of a signed digraph G with the help of rooted cycles.

Theorem 2: Consider a signed digraph G which contains a spanning tree. The Laplacian matrix L satisfies the result R1) if and only if one of the following condition holds: C1) G has no rooted cycles (that is, G has exactly one root); C2) G has rooted cycles which are all positive. In addition, L satisfies the result R2) if and only if C3) G has at least one negative rooted cycle.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, the consensus problem for multi-agent systems associated with signed digraphs has been studied, for which a unified analysis framework applicable in both continuous-time and discrete-time domains has been presented. We have shown that there exist various consensus performances for multi-agent systems associated with signed digraphs which are not strongly connected but only have spanning trees. In spite of this fact, we have proposed a class of interval bipartite consensus problems to derive consensus results in a unified manner by investigating the state convergence of agents. We can enable the multi-agent system with its state converging to a constant vector depending only on the initial states of root agents if and only if there exist no rooted cycles or the existing rooted cycles are all positive. This result includes as special cases the traditional consensus and bipartite consensus results of multi-agent systems (e.g., see [10], [15]). In addition, the multi-agent system can achieve the state stability if and only if its associated signed digraph has at least one negative rooted cycle. This improves stability results of multi-agent systems associated with structurally unbalanced signed digraphs that are required to be strongly connected [15]. Illustrative examples have been also employed to demonstrate the given consensus results for agents under signed digraphs.

We have only considered linear protocols of agents with the first-order dynamics. Some possible extensions of the proposed analysis include consensus, as well as finite-time or fixed-time consensus, in the presence of nonlinear dynamics, higher-order dynamics, communication time-delays, external disturbances, and switching topologies.
